>>178202231
This is ultimately true. Little Kuriboh was the only one among them all that actually had any real talent. Granted, some of the others were moderately good writers. HBI2K, for example, was an absolutely shit voice actor, but some of his jokes were funny. Antfish was also pretty good from what I remember. LK was the only one that both had consistently funny writing and was a great voice actor. I can still laugh at his work, because his approach was to relentlessly mock the characters, premise, and overall stupidity of the show he was parodying. The dumber the show, the more absurd the humor, such as with Naruto the Abridged Series and some of the Yugioh offshoots. This is where TeamFourStar got it completely wrong. They seemed to be making a tribute to the show and to be celebrating it, rather than tearing it apart like LK did with his stuff. That's why their work just wasn't as funny.

So I just watched all the Japanese Godzilla movies for the first time over the last two weeks. I haven't(and don't really plan to) watched any of the US movies or any of the animes. This is how I feel about it:

1) Shōwa era is pure soul. Even the shittiest ones have charm somehow. Godzilla vs. Gigan was my favorite.

2) Heisei era is complete garbage. I'm not even going to attempt to say why because I can't even process it. Every one of the films had me totally lose interest and start skipping around to watch the fights.

3) Millennium era is my jam and Godzilla 2000 is my pick for #1 Godzilla movie of all time. Best suit design of the franchise with the kiryugoji small head hooded look. Final Wars had me turning it off at less than 10 mins in. WTF were they thinking?

4) Shin Godzilla may be the most Japanese movie ever made.

i kinda agree that the fixation with turning LOTR into some epic masculinity stuff is weird considering it's a very sensitive story at heart (it's one of the reasons women also like it so much). the most important plot is the one about two kids pouring their hearts for one another and stuff, it's hardly alpha male material.
but I dunno, a prophesized hero doesn't mean it's boring desu. I don't know if your point is "it's bad because we can tell the protagonist is gonna win", because that's 99% of stories. Tension and excitement always come from HOW the hero will get out of that one, not IF, which is what brings the more exciting parts of telling a story. Bravery, quick thinking, power of friendship, combat skills, whatever, all more interesting than "woah he can die here!!!!!", which is always one-note and gets boring quick.
If your point is "he wins too easily because he's destined to" then you're just being overdramatic because Aragorn earns his ending like every hero out there, the fact he is destined to be king is just the veil of hope to give them a reason to fight impossible odds.

>>178201687
I never said that gratuitous use and shock value of uncalled deaths of protags makes a story any better. But there should be some kind of thrill, not just jolly little folks going on about and making their way to the fairytale ending.
Put at least some weight into the antagonist, make him less cartoonishly bad, add feeling of dread or helplessness where you can feel that there's something indeed at stake, or kind turn of event like turning the tides in a witted way. Having this fairytale go for hours is not for everyone. Sanctifying it is ridiculous. It's like saying Naruto or any anime that share the very same themes (power of friendship, unity and diversity is great, etc.). But do you see yourself constantly evangelize Naruto or One Piece?
You don't need to ask me what kind of movies I like to make a judgement. You may as well ask me what's my favorite band or song.
I was just stating how disappointed I was at a saga that was supposed to be something universally acclaimed and considered as peak "man" thing. Given the sea of soulless movies we get these past years, I was only searching for that movie "I kept hearing about a long time ago" and was afraid of missing out.
I believe that there's no consensus (apart from the fact that the industry is dead since two decades) as to what is the GOAT when it comes to movies, because that would be utter fanboyism. People have different tastes and more importantly people go through phases. As we grow old, we start to lose interest in what we used to like or even be embarrassed for liking it. And it's perfectly normal and healthy behavior. The opposite is not.

posts.sub: Avatar 2 is one of the most immoral movies ever made
posts.com:
In this film, James Cameron sells us on what is possibly the most sinister lie ever constructed

>Nature is Peaceful, and man is only violent because he is not in tune with nature

Of course, what Cameron has forgotten is that without violence, nature cannot be balanced. But not according to James Cameron, because in this movie there's only a single act of predation, in which an insane predatory fish literally destroys an entire reef just to get at a single small meal. Instead, we see the "predatory" species of Pandora literally being used as an "immune system" by the planet's eldritch brain fungus deity. And yet, we never see these creatures hunt or kill other animals. We only ever see them used as a defense system- as if the beings on the planet have no agency, and are simply pawns of the great eldritch mind fungus.

And thus we come to the crux of the immorality- Cameron portrays paradise as a place where there is no free will. Because Pandora cannot function if the creatures in it have agency. What is the drive of the creatures on Pandora? What do they seek? Do they seek to procreate? If so, why is there not overpopulation? Does the eldritch brain fungus decide who is and is not allowed to have children in order to prevent this?

I have no doubt that if James Cameron had the power, he would flip a switch that allowed him to mind control every single living being on this planet so that he could turn it into his perfect paradise of naked monkey catgirls running around with zero free will, zero agency, zero suffering. Because at his core, James Cameron is possibly the most evil man to ever exist. He does not value free will. He despises agency. He vilifies ambition. He sells you a lie, a sugarcoated image of our primitive past, omitting the death from disease, starvation, human sacrifice, and tribal warfare. Does famine never happen on Pandora? Has there never been a natural disaster in it's history? Has it never been struck by an asteroid. How long has the average temperature of the planet been the same?

James Cameron can't answer these questions, because he's too busy jerking off to how cool whales are and how all people are evil, and how much better the world would be if he could just mind control them.

The god of Pandora is not Eywa- it is James Cameron. He has imposed his will, his agency- his dream of a magical fairytale paradise where predators don't exist, where there is no conflict, and where all things exist in perfect balance under his careful supervision. It is the world from the mind of a central planner- the self proclaimed "all knower" who has time and time again dangled the promise of paradise if you only forfeit your agency, your choice, your free will. And thus we finally set upon what Avatar truly is: a masturbatory fantasy of a man who dreams of controlling living creatures to participate in his imagined paradise- and let us all hope that James Cameron can never enforce his evil will on mankind, and that his heinous desires remain constrained to the imaginary realm of Pandora

>>178199672
>dude family is good
>dude family stick together

Well yes, but WHY? Why is Family good? Why should family stick together? Why do we care about these things? Why are they good? These are instincts that are programmed deep into us evolutionarily, because they create incredibly strong bonds that bind groups together, and groups will always have a natural advantage with strength in numbers.

It figures that James Cameron would make a movie all about an evolved instinct, set in a world where the total lack of conflict would in fact, lead to total debauchery and a complete lack of any sort of familial connection. The concept of family one forged out of necessity, survival, and milennia of evolutionary biology. Pandora is a planet with no evolution. Nothing ever changes on it. Not the weather, not the plants, not the animals, certainly not the culture of the inhabitants. So why is family important? There's no dangerous predators. There's no potential for famine or the threat of a hostile tribe.

So again, I ask- why is family important on Pandora? They're not humans. They're not from earth. They don't share our evolutionary history. So, why is family important to the Navi?

posts.name: Anonymous

>>178192719
As cool as it is and as many considerations for reality as it has, it's still entirely impossible, no matter what technology you're using. Even if it was using 99.99% efficient engines for its antimatter-powered deceleration phase, it would still produce megatons-worth of joules of waste energy that would melt the ship. Same for the acceleration phase - even if it reflects 99.99% of the energy received from the laser, that last 0.01% would still be atom bombs worth of heat each second.
This video has a solid analysis of the energy problems:
https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=D6H1TxRGLUc
There's simply no way to redirect that much energy and not vaporize your engine, radiators, and everything else attached.

To play devil's advocate, Kylo won in the movie 3 duel. He was in control the entire fight and had it won. It is somewhat like the Vader/Luke fight in Return. Luke lost that fight, it's his lowest point and he failed. He gave in to the dark side. However, his greatest victory comes immediately after when he throws away his weapon and submits himself to die as a Jedi, like his father.

I really do hate the Disney films, but you can see the clear intent and OT influence on that movie 3 fight. At the start Rey is the one to draw her weapon, in anger, while Kylo doesn't even take out his lightsaber until a while after. It mirrors Luke drawing his weapon first in the force cave in Empire, as well as him beating down Vader in Return. Both moments of great moral/spiritual defeat.

The problem, obviously, is that it doesn't work because Rey always wins anyway and she never really grows. She has a generic half-assed attempt at "she's kind of falling to the dark side, because this is Star Wars and that's what our protagonists always have to do".

It's a shit fight, but my points stand.

When you start at a university, you start by teaching 100 level courses. 1/100 kids you teach actually give a shit about chemistry. The rest are there to fill a humanities credit or a pre-req. posts.name: TrekVirgin
posts.com:
Really liked this one!
A tad bit flawed because… what the fuck was up with “another earth”? But other than that dropped concept, the episode had a nice mystery, a cool planetary conundrum, interesting stakes and for some reason children in the apocalypse/lost boys stuff appeals to me personally.
It was refreshing to see the show on a backlot set rather than in-studio. Made the place feel more real, and allowed for a bit more creativity in the camera direction.
The acting was a highlight here, not just in the core cast, who sold the less visual stakes, and performed their more angry/intimate moments very well, but also the kids! The head Onlie was really giving it his all.
The Kirk and little girl stuff toed the line a little, but she’s a 300 year old so it’s okay? (Wouldn’t be the first time Star Trek pulls an anime cliche before it became one lol)
Happy to see Rand again, now that I know she’s gonna leave.
Once again, the episode wasn’t completely tight because of the unresolved mystery, but it made for a cool setting seeing the cast interact with a decayed version of the 60’s. Regardless, what it did choose to tackle with the virus and the endless childhood among the rubble of a decayed civilization was interesting, and as a production it stood out.

>Mfw Kirk literally said “nah, that loli is too old”

Good episode. Onto the next.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's interesting comparing how TOS and TNG handle similar stories. This is something I noticed upon rewatching TNG after watching TOS for the first time. A couple of examples come to mind:

>TOS episode: Kirk violates the Prime Directive by providing weapons to one side in a civil war, to keep the conflict "balanced" - this is portrayed as a good thing (despite Spock correctly pointing out the PD violation)
>TNG episode: Seemingly as a direct criticism of this scenario, an old retired captain deals with the consequences of having done this - him providing weapons to balance out the war resulted in the war continuing for decades, killing millions more people than would otherwise have happened if the war was "unbalanced" and one side stomped the other quickly

>TOS episode: Kirk and crew are tasked with infiltrating the Romulans and stealing their tech to give the Federation an advantage in their cold war - this is portrayed as a good thing and no one questions its legality or wisdom
>TNG episode: The Pegasus's attempt to give the Federation the Romulans' cloaking tech is strongly condemned by hardcore moral paragon Picard because it isn't legal, even though it would significantly help the Federation in its cold war with the Romulans

I suppose it's a reflection of the softer, more pacifistic liberalism of the late 80s and early 90s compared to the more hard-edged, pragmatic attitude of the late 60s peak Cold War mindset.

posts.name: TrekVirgin
posts.com:
A murder mystery, a dark spot in Kirk’s past, a sexual sparring match with a pretty blonde woman, and a dramatic climax. Fitting, an episode centered around a traveling theater company is the most melodramatic so far (not necessarily in a bad way).
This one is good, but i’d say it’s just shy of one of the greats. I really liked the more roguish side of Kirk in this episode, battling his duty/morals and desire for vengeance, Lenore was great (both as a tantalizing object of Kirk’s affections, and her role in the climax). I also really bought Karidian’s performance as well, rather than making him a mustache twirler, instead a man who made a hard decision and plagued with regret was a really nice touch.
That said, the bridge wrap up was one of my least favorites thus far. Kirk’s troubles were reflected upon nicely, but the resolution of Lenore felt like a major cop out .
That said, I enjoyed the more theatrical dialogue and dramatic arc here, I could see someone believing the episode to be a little pretentious, but the classical tragedy of it all with almost light… noir elements…? had me rooting in its favor. I particularly found Kirk’s musings on women to be more endearing than eyeroll-worthy as it might have been.
Had the landing been stuck, this would be way up there for me.
Never get tired of tangentially relevant scenes of crew banter, Spock and McCoy’s scene regarding alcohol stands out, and I also like seeing the return of the rec room.

>I half expected the crew to applaud, not knowing the climax was real instead of a performance lol

Good episode. Onto the next.

posts.name: TrekVirgin
posts.com:
>It’s a Spock episode
Immediately GOATED.
Naw, but seriously, really great episode from beginning to end. A simple “stranded” plot with a ticking clock turns into a character study for Spock as he’s presented with the challenges of command directly.
What struck me most about this episode is I really felt the tension, perhaps the most out of any episode so far. Logically, of course, I know that Spock, McCoy and Scotty won’t die in a one off, but the stakes were just so high as the problems compounded, And I found myself sucked in anyway. Already I’ve come to care about these characters, Kirk’s unwavering conviction to save his crew coupled with the fact that this episode was plotted particularly well for tension and catharsis really came together wonderfully.
The model work done in this episode was a bit of a cut above the rest. It’s still 60’s effects, but I liked those little shuttles. Monkey men were cool, I’m glad we never got a good look at them, it’s better in your head. Most of all I enjoyed seeing Spock challenged by the irrationality of his allies and enemies, and despite being in the wrong for most of the episode, ultimately doing the right thing for those under his command whenever possible.
The ending, with Spock performing an illogical action, out of desperation/hope, the reaction from Kirk as he’s saved his dear friends in the nick of time (sold excellently by Shatner) and then the good hearted ribbing of Spock at the end was practically a perfect end to the episode.
No big sci-fi ideas, nor any major resonant themes, but a great character study with tension and stakes, and a wholly fulfilling climax puts this up there for me.
The moment of Kirk seeing the streak of light along the planet reminded me of one of my favorite climaxes in all of fiction (in a good way) Gunbuster

>Must resist… becoming… Spock fanboy drone…

Great episode, onto the next.

posts.name: TrekVirgin
posts.com:
This show really can do almost anything, can’t it?
A court drama centered around a potentially disgraced Captain Kirk, with the added hook of the prosecution being a former lover of Kirk’s, made for a fun little conundrum.
Some great lines this episode, dialogue was snappier than usual.
I’ll admit, I was fooled by the twist, and had totally fallen for the red herring (I thought I was being smart, ha!). This episode did a great job of building up the importance of being a starship captain, and what it really means. In addition, it showcased the crew’s accomplishments, and their loyalty to Kirk. The guest stars (especially Cogley who was quirky and fun) were nice for an episode.
The twist to the mystery being good and leading to a nice action climax was icing on top, I really thought we’d be stuck in the courtroom all episode.
Nothing mindblowing, but this show’s average episode is still a consistently good time.

>Noticed one goof… Spock’s heart doesn’t belong there McCoy!

Solid average episode. Looking to do one more, which in this case is a two parter. Depending on how that goes I might do one post for both.

I recently watched TMP with the commentary track and they're talking about how the norm for sci fi ships at the time was to make them extremely detailed on the outside, think of what you see in 2001 or Star Wars. posts.name: Anonymous

>>178194770
Because they'd have to be like 10mm thick, which would weigh about 25kg and be too heavy to carry for a prolonged period of time. Battles were won with maneuver, firepower and discipline. Massive and overly heavy shields seriously hinder maneuver and changing formation, would be too heavy to carry for an entire battle, would mean fewer troops firing, would prevent file firing as the shields would be in the way, and would hinder launching a bayonet charge as everyone would be hindered by the slower moving ones with shields. They'd also be easily countered by artillery, and make the unit more vulnerable to cavalry due to hindering forming square. The only use for a 25kg shield would be in storming a breach as part of a siege or other offensive action.

No you cant put them on wheels.

>>178196991
The casualties caused by which weapon varied massively depending on the theatre, campaign or battle. In a battle where cavalry or a bayonet charge were decisive, those will cause the most casualties, or if one army has a huge artillery advantage+a good position, then artillery will, and so on. Musketry often caused the most casualties, as infantry melees rarely lasted long on an open field, although cavalry ones were vicious and in sieges melee combat was much more protracted. Muskets were however more likely to merely wound if hit, compared to a cannon.
>>178201195
Because everyone was an obvious target, it prevented friendly fire or misidentification as it made identification easy from a distance, and made unit cohesion in a melee or close order easier for the soldiers as its easy to identify allies immediately. Friendly fire happens constantly today, it happened a lot less often then. They'd also maneuver and command mostly in visual range a lot of the time so its convenient to be able to distinguish your formations from a distance, and not confuse them for enemy ones.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>178179868
Shockingly enough, somewhere between 17-22mm. In practice though, you have two eyes working in tandem and your brain does an absolute shit-ton of real-time image post-processing so something in the 56mm range is probably the best approximation in terms of a camera lens. Our brains actually actively flatten out the lens curvature of what we’re seeing in order to better understand distances between objects, in many respects 120mm-150mm might be more accurate for specifically how we perceive faces due to this.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>178196131
60K. Halfway through I filed a zero income tax return, together with a schedule for a rent refund credit. The state wrote me back and didn't audit me, but they figured my credit application was fishy so they sent me a letter demanding about fifteen different things in very precise detail. I wrote back, proudly noting that "during the year, I did not find or seek employment. Here are all the materials you've requested of me. I therefore look forward to receiving a refund". I got my refund.

During my elysium, I wandered the city as I pleased, rediscovered my love of reading, took up independent research projects, and frequented the museums. I still do all of these things, just to a lesser extent. Happily the job pays well enough and is low stress enough that I actually have mental energy for these things most nights, especially since I'm not trapped in any personal situation (such has a marriage, family, friendships etc) involving caring for anyone other than myself.

You don't really need to know the language, but knowing a few words and phrases never hurts. Also, you shouldn't really have to worry about getting a new bank or anything, but I have a USAA military bank account, idk how other banks work overseas. And doing it is pretty simple, just some visa paperwork, although it varies from country to country and covid has changed a lot of shit up adding more bullshit to the process. A full on move is a different story.
Expenses vary. If you're backpacking/traveling around you could survive dirt fucking cheap. However, when I was in Ha Noi, I was paying a little more than $800 a month for a modern 2 bed room apartment overlooking west lake. Food is cheap, like $1 for street food, maybe $3 for a full meal at a local restaurant. Beers are like 50 cents. And I just pretty much did what I normally do in the US but way cheaper and in a tropical climate. Go to bars, take a trip to the beach, stay at home on my PC, etc. Hookers exist but really aren't necessary. That's more for the old retired expats. Just be white and attractive.

I bought a lot of books, and even read a few. I think there were some car repairs in there too. I also didn't mention that I drank nightly, and still do.

In the fall of '15 I figured this happy period was coming to an end and I'd definitely have to work again next spring or so (this is how it turned out), but I had an opportunity to see my favorite group (Autechre) in Chicago so I also spent on that, figured it would be worth having the story to tell and to have seen them twice. Overall that project must have run something from about 1-1.5K. Stayed in a peaceful shitty motel outside O'Hare with a bullet hole in the window. I believe it was two nights. The parking lot had a nice vibe, just lots of working poor scrub types enjoying the warm weather and peacefully smoking on the balcony and such. Jewel Osco, a local chain.

Drove around the north side without incident, most hectic traffic I'd ever been in but nothing happened so it was fine. Did a standard touristy tower+museum package, that was also great. Before the show I made a point of getting out by the lake and just seeing a large body of water, which is unusual for me. Show was next to Wrigley (the Cusb would win the following year). On the way home, I took a Wisconsin Death Trip and rolled past the killing grounds of both Dahmer and Gein, since I figured I would not pass this way again any time soon.
